title: Application of Î¶-factor Microanalysis to Quantify Grain Boundary Enrichment in Eu-doped B6O
content: Grain boundary enrichment influences bulk material properties such as intergranular fracture of brittle materials, ionic conductivity of solid-state electrolytes, and grain boundary mobility of polycrystals [1]. Therefore, grain boundary enrichment is often an emphasis of materials design, and the extent of interfacial segregation is measured to identify grain boundary related processing-microstructure-property relationships. Recent examples of controlling grain boundary behavior have been focused on promoting intergranular fracture in ultrahard ceramics, particularly boron carbide [2] and boron suboxide [3]. The aim was to improve fracture toughness by driving enrichment of Si and/or other glass forming additives to grain boundaries in B4C and B6O, thereby weakening interfacial strength and enabling crack deflection mechanisms. Grain boundary segregation can be qualitatively confirmed using high-resolution imaging (i.e., scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM)), but there is a greater need to quantify enrichment using microanalysis (i.e., X-ray energy dispersive spectrometry (XEDS)) to relate material response to processing and structure. However, there are significant challenges in accurately quantifying grain boundary enrichment using microanalysis, particularly for low-Z materials such as borides, carbides, and oxides. The goal of this work was to develop STEM-XEDS microanalysis methods to quantify grain boundary enrichment and obtain a fundamental understanding of grain boundary composition driven grain growth and intergranular fracture behaviors in boron-rich ceramics.
